data.title: The Princess from Kyiv
data.meta_description: The love life of Henry, King of the Franks, seemed to be as obstacle-ridden as the Throne (1031–1060) of his still fragile kingdom. Since his beginning as a young monarch, Henry had faced the…
data.text:
The love life of Henry, King of the Franks, seemed to be as obstacle-ridden as the Throne (1031–1060) of his still fragile kingdom. Since his beginning as a young monarch, Henry had faced the conquest and loss of territories, with disputes and battles against his own parents, tensions with his brother and several compromises he had to make for regions such as Burgundy and Lorraine (which would make him go down in history with a less than brilliant reputation).

Regarding marriage, he saw the negotiations to wed the daughter of the Duke of Aquitaine fail; later, he got engaged to the young Matilda of Germania, but she died before the nuptials were in the cards; in the same year, he married Matilda of Frisia… who also died, along with their little daughter, shortly after.

Tired of such bad luck — and of constant kinship issues with prospective brides — Henry came up with an idea as ambitious as it was romantic: seeking a wife as far away as possible.

He wanted a noblewoman with whom he didn’t have the slightest chance of sharing blood ties.

His choice fell on Anna Yaroslavna, daughter of Yaroslav I the Wise, Grand Prince of Kyiv. The fame of her delicate beauty and her remarkable…
